headline: Early Start with John Berman and Zoraida Sambolin
subHeadline: Trump Charged With Four Counts In January 5th Criminal Case; Special Counsel: Office Will Seek A Speedy Trial; GOP Rushes To Trump's Defense, Continues Attacks On DOJ. Aired 5:30-6a ET

utterances.speaker: POPPY HARLOW, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Tim, for Americans waking up this morning and thinking well, if this goes to trial before the election and he's convicted, he can't be elected -- he can't serve as president -- what do you say to them?

utterances.speaker: NAFTALI
utterances.sentences: Well, Poppy, I'm not a lawyer and I -- but I suspect from having watched all of this unfold that we can expect the former president to appeal. Should this reach a jury and should a jury find him guilty he will appeal, in which case this would be under appeal.That is a great question but I think that's a question for the -- for the conscience of each and every voter. Can you, in good faith, vote for a person who has been found guilty of undermining your right to have your vote counted? I think that's a question for each and every voter and as a result, it's something they have to decide.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Tim Naftali, we appreciate it as always. I just kind of want to listen to you talk about this stuff. I think it puts it in focus in a moment where everything seems very fast, very fluid, and people are numb to a lot of things. Appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: NAFTALI
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Phil.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Special counsel Jack Smith says he's looking for a speedy trial for Donald Trump. We're going to talk about that timing next.

utterances.speaker: JACK SMITH, SPECIAL COUNSEL
utterances.sentences: In this case, my office will seek a speedy trial so that our evidence can be tested in court and judged by a jury of citizens.

utterances.speaker: JOHN LAURO, TRUMP ATTORNEY
utterances.sentences: The government has had three years to investigate this and now they want to rush this to trial in the middle of a political season. What does that tell you?(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: That is Trump's attorney with Kaitlan last night talking about the fact he thinks it will take nine or 10 months to see this play out. We'll see.Let's bring back our experts. Jeremy, to you, Jack Smith's -- his statement last night -- the special counsel -- was about two minutes. He chose every word, I have no doubt, incredibly carefully. The fact that he said speedy trial, what does it tell you?

utterances.speaker: JEREMY SALAND, FORMER MANHATTAN PROSECUTOR
utterances.sentences: I think that this case sort of jumps over the other two cases. And not to disrespect the Manhattan district attorney's office -- that's a different animal -- but in terms of the confidential document espionage act case, this is so much more critical and so much -- and I think easier, too, as I briefly mentioned before. I think it happens before that May date.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Because -- so explain why. So you're talking Alvin Bragg here in New York and --

utterances.speaker: SALAND
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: -- has signaled -- not explicitly said but signaled a willingness --

utterances.speaker: SALAND
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: -- to be open to moving that March date.Mar-a-Lago -- you have classified documents -- highly classified documents, so that can slow things down in terms of getting clearance. What can a jury see, what can they not? Are those the two reasons why you think this could be speedier?

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Then why not bring it first? Why bring the Mar-a-Lago documents case first?

utterances.speaker: SALAND
utterances.sentences: Because I can't say -- none of us here can say what was happening in those grand juries -- the extent of those investigations. How it took them to get up to speed. What they needed to do. So there's a lot of different reasons.But that sort of quarterback after the fact -- armchair quarterback -- I don't want to speculate about that.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: You're sitting on a panel on TV, man. That's --

utterances.speaker: SALAND
utterances.sentences: True. You know what? That's a fair statement. I need to sit somewhere else.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: No.(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: SALAND
utterances.sentences: But all kidding -- but all -- but all kidding aside, there's so much that's going on and this is such a heavy case -- both are heavy -- that we would be speculating so much. But this case now, currently, has to move forward in a speedy way.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: This is a point that Scott Jennings, who worked for McConnell, said over and over last night. He was adamant about the American people cannot vote in a general election until they know the outcome of this -- whether we know if Trump is convicted or not.The interesting thing, John, is that that's not how the law works.

utterances.speaker: JOHN AVLON, CNN SENIOR POLICY ANALYST AND ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: The law works -- you bring a case when it's ready. And a judge has a lot of say here, and a defendant has more say than a prosecution on when something goes to trial. There's a deference to a defendant if they say they file motions, need more time, et cetera.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Yes, and Trump's team has consistently showed a preference for delay because they believe that delay will be denial in that case. I mean, to some extent, Donald Trump is running to stay out of prison. Let's be honest about that. He's fundraising off this, he's delaying it. He's saying they can't possibly prosecute me because this -- we're in the middle of a political season.And, indeed, the prospect of a possible hypothetical self-pardon should he become president, right? And all these hypotheticals because we are in this unprecedented situation. The important thing to remember that I think, in part, you're getting at is people might not fully appreciate that someone can be elected to office from prison, including the office of the presidency.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: That's what I was sort of trying to talk --

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: -- to Tim Naftali about. It's such uncharted territory.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Yes, completely surreal. But there are cases -- James Michael Curley, former mayor of Boston, elected from prison for a local office there. It's very rare, as it should be because for most folks, being in prison would be a disqualifier. For most folks, I would think trying to overturn an election would be a disqualifier.I will say again the Constitution, 14th Amendment, section 3, specifically says that if you've taken an oath to uphold the Constitution and then participate, give aid or comfort to an insurrection, you will be barred from holding federal office vis-a-vis a vote for (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Do we have an extra hour to add here to debate this 14th Amendment section with John Avlon?

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: I would be delighted to talk about that at length because everyone says this is so -- this is -- this is impossible, but it's in the Constitution. And if look at the debates around it, it was designed to be prospective; not just about the Civil War. But here endeth the lesson for this morning.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Yes. Stay with us. They literally walked themselves, right? They saw a rock, they saw a hard place, and they're like let's just go stand --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: -- I love it -- repeatedly.Lawmakers in Washington are calling it a sad or dark day for America but for very different reasons. That's coming up next. (COMMERCIAL) (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) REP. ZOE LOFGREN (D-CA):  This is a sad day that an ex-president would have committed such terrible things that the Department of Justice had to bring an indictment. On the other hand, the good news is we're a country of laws and no one is above the law. It's not just the foot soldiers being held to account, but the people who made the plot overturn the Constitution and the election. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: LAUREN FOX, CNN CONGRESSIONAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean, Phil, this is a really familiar playbook that we have seen repeatedly on Capitol Hill. What's different about this indictment, of course, is how it personally affected members of Congress on that day -- on January 6 when they were trying to certify the election.You do hear from Republican leaders very swift statements yesterday basically defending President Donald Trump and his actions, arguing that the Justice Department is weaponized. And you heard from some of Trump's staunchest defenders yesterday that they want to go after the office of Jack Smith in terms of funding that office. But over the course of the last several weeks, this was a very orchestrated effort to make sure that Donald Trump had defense from Republicans on Capitol Hill. They were coordinating that response, making sure that they were in a position to defend him. Meanwhile, in the Senate, you see a very different story playing out, Phil, and that's because we haven't heard from Mitch McConnell. We haven't heard from John Thune. And we're not going to hear from them, likely, for weeks because Republicans are on recess, which means you can't go through the halls of the Capitol getting a response in the way that you normally could because lawmakers are away for a very long recess, Phil. So you are just seeing that split screen play out between the House and Senate Republicans once again.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: All right, Lauren Fox for us in Washington. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: What timing that they don't have to follow Laura and Manu --

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: They are -- they are so lucky.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: -- chasing them down the hall to answer questions.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: And they know it, too.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: They know it.Donald Trump due in court in Washington, D.C. tomorrow morning. What that will look like ahead.
